;;我;;2019年;联邦艾伦·奥尔布赖特（Alan Albright）法官向一群律师做了陈述。他是德克萨斯州韦科市法院的唯一法官，法院位于一家糖果店附近。这次演讲的主题是“为什么您应该在‘Hey Sugar’街对面提交下一个专利案件”。

;

;知识产权听到他的主张的律师显然被说服了。据法律分析公司 Lex Machina 称，在被任命为法官不到两年后，他就处理了全国近 20% 的专利案件。到2021年，他的占有率达到23%。来自纽约和加利福尼亚州的白鞋律师代表 Google 和英特尔等客户组成的审判团队开始涌入德克萨斯州中部一座拥有 14 万人口的城市韦科。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;比尔韦特曼 (Bill Wetterman) 是一名房地产开发商，也是韦科人，他发现了一个商机。 2021 年，他开设了 Legal Lawfts，这是一个可出租的办公空间——用术语来说就是“作战室”——配备了安全摄像头、备用互联网，并应要求提供无麸质奥利奥。

;

;在韦科，Wetterman 先生的竞争对手包括 Connect Litigation，这是一家在市中心经营几个作战室的公司。但 Connect 的业务集中在东北约 200 英里处。 “专利案卷”在马歇尔是一个熟悉的术语，马歇尔是路易斯安那州边境附近一座褪色但古色古香的小镇，约有 24,000 人。 2000 年至 2020 年间，联邦法院提交的所有专利案件中，超过 17% 发生在德克萨斯州东区，大约有 13,500 起。相比之下，大多数美国大公司的注册地特拉华州的案件数量不到 10,000 起；大型科技公司所在的加州北区的数量不到 5,000 家。

;

;T. 1999 年至 2011 年担任马歇尔联邦法官的约翰·沃德 (John Ward) 是该镇令人费解的受欢迎程度的罪魁祸首。专利案件是技术性的。法官必须对敏感源代码的共享进行仲裁，例如：原告认为这将证明他们的案子；被告担心他们的秘密会泄露，因此进行抵抗。韦科的专利诉讼律师马克·西格蒙德 (Mark Siegmund) 表示，他们还解释专利文字的实际含义，这可能是“结果决定性的”。案件也可能需要数年时间才能进入审判阶段。

;

;沃德先生了解到，北加州法院已经实施了当地规则，以建立律师所谓的“确定性” “——一个可预测的过程——进入笨重的案例。他采用了类似的方法，并对其进行了调整以优先考虑速度。诉讼当事人进入审判所需的时间是加利福尼亚州的一半。天普大学的保罗·古格利乌扎 (Paul Gugliuzza) 表示，大约在同一时期，“专利流氓诉讼也激增”，他指的是拥有不良专利并寻求快速、廉价和解的原告。到 2010 年代中期，沃德先生的继任者罗德尼·吉尔斯特拉普 (Rodney Gilstrap) 掌握了全国约四分之一的专利案件。

;;

;美国帕茨维尔

;

;马歇尔的案件数量挤满了法院，并促进了市中心的商业发展。一家酒店订阅了 ;PACER;（法庭记录在线数据库），以跟踪潜在客户。显然是为了让当地人（即陪审员）更喜欢它，经常被告的三星赞助了法院对面的一个溜冰场。 TiVo 在牲畜拍卖会上花费 10,000 美元购买了一头冠军公牛，并将其命名为 TiVo。

;

;这让一些人感到不安。联邦法官应该是通才，法院不应该为当地经济提供动力。特拉华州专利诉讼律师安德鲁·拉塞尔 (Andrew Russell) 表示，这些规则“往往对原告更加友好”。被告经常试图将案件转移到其他地方。但这在一定程度上是因为快速的节奏适合原告，因为财力雄厚的被告有能力拖延诉讼。马歇尔的长期专利诉讼律师迈克尔·史密斯 (Michael Smith) 表示，早期，东区的判决是一边倒的，因为豪华的辩护律师在陪审团面前辩论“糟糕”。东区的判决现已符合全国平均水平。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;但是马歇尔案的情况非常糟糕，以至于最高法院在 2017 年实际上让原告变得更加困难在那里提起诉讼，要求被告在被起诉的地方拥有“正常且稳定的”业务。苹果关闭了附近的商店。 （三星并没有这样做，尽管有溜冰场，但去年在马歇尔陪审团的判决中，三星仍被判 3.03 亿美元。）

;

;到 2021 年韦科的专利申请同样迅速，这要归功于当地的规定，也引起了密切关注。最高法院首席大法官约翰·罗伯茨承认参议员们对“专利诉讼极度集中”的担忧。从 2022 年开始，韦科专利案件需要进行抽签，这样德克萨斯州西区 12 名法官中的任何一位都可以抽签。 2023 年，总体上提交的专利案件有所减少，韦科的专利案件数量急剧下降。

;

;专利诉讼可以合理地保证专门法院的成立，类似美国用来处理破产案件的系统，配备了经验丰富的法官。德克萨斯大学的史蒂夫·弗拉德克 (Steve Vladeck) 表示：“国会可能认为建立国家专利法院是明智之举，这是有令人信服的理由的。” “问题在于，决定的是国会，而不是德克萨斯州第 37 大城市的法官。”事实上，韦科在该州排名第 24 位。马歇尔并列第 138 位。;■;

;;G;;Z 代;接管。在富裕国家，至少有 2.5 亿人出生于 1997 年至 2012 年之间。其中大约一半人现在有工作。在普通美国人的;工作场所;中， Z 世代（有时也称为“Zoomers”）全职工作的人数即将超过全职婴儿潮一代的人数，这些人出生于 1945 年至 1964 年，他们的职业生涯正在逐渐结束（见图 1）。 Z 世代也在攫取权力：美国现在有超过 6,000 名 Zoomer 首席执行官和 1,000 名 Zoomer 政客。随着这一代人的影响力越来越大，公司、政府和投资者需要了解这一点。

;

;专家们对;该群体; 。薯片制造商菲多利 (Frito-Lay) 最近的“研究”发现，Z 世代非常喜欢“手指上留下残留物的零食”，例如奶酪粉。然而，不同世代的性格也表现出更深层次的差异，部分原因在于他们成长的经济背景。在 20 年代高通货膨胀时期成年的德国人开始厌恶物价上涨。经历过大萧条的美国人倾向于避免投资股票市场。

;;
;;
;

;许多人认为 Z 世代的定义是焦虑。此类担忧者包括纽约大学社会心理学家乔纳森·海特 (Jonathan Haidt)，他的新书《;焦虑的一代;”正在掀起波澜。从某些方面来说，Z 世代是不同寻常的。与过去相比，今天的年轻人不太可能建立人际关系。他们更有可能感到沮丧，或者说他们出生时被分配了错误的性别。他们不太可能喝酒、做爱、谈恋爱——事实上也不太可能做任何令人兴奋的事情。官方数据显示，15 岁至 24 岁之间的美国人平均每天仅花 38 分钟进行面对面社交，低于 2000 年代的近一个小时。 Haidt 先生将责任归咎于智能手机及其支持的社交媒体。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;他的书引起了巨大的反响。 4 月 10 日，阿肯色州州长萨拉·赫卡比·桑德斯 (Sarah Huckabee Sanders) 回应了海特的观点，概述了监管儿童使用智能手机和社交媒体的计划。英国政府正在考虑采取类似措施。但并非所有人都同意海特先生的论点。 Z 世代的焦虑情绪掩盖了该群体的另一种独特之处。从财务角度来看，Z 世代的表现非常出色。这反过来又改变了这一代人与工作的关系。

;

;考虑一下 Z 世代之前的群体：出生于 1981 年之间的千禧一代1996 年。许多人进入劳动力市场时，世界正受到 2007-09 年全球金融危机的影响，年轻人在这场危机中遭受的损失尤为严重。 2012-14 年，超过一半想要工作的西班牙年轻人找不到工作。希腊的青年失业率甚至更高。布兰妮·斯皮尔斯 (Britney Spears) 于 2013 年发行的热门歌曲《Work Bitch》向年轻的千禧一代传达了毫不妥协的信息：如果你想要美好的事物，就必须努力奋斗。

;

;离开教育的 Z 世代面临着截然不同的情况。发达国家的青年失业率约为 13%，自 1991 年以来从未如此低过（见图 2）。希腊的青年失业率已较峰值下降了一半。旅游胜地卡拉马塔的酒店经营者抱怨劳动力短缺，这在几年前是不可想象的。流行歌曲反映了时代精神。 2022 年，碧昂斯 (Beyoncé) 歌曲中的主角夸口道：“我刚刚辞去了工作”。深受美国 Z 世代欢迎的 21 岁歌手奥利维亚·罗德里戈 (Olivia Rodrigo) 抱怨说，前恋人的“事业真的起飞了”。

;
;;
;

;许多人选择学习有助于找到工作的科目。在英国和美国，Z 世代正在回避人文学科，转而追求更明显有用的东西，比如经济和工程学。在没有上大学的人中，职业资格越来越受欢迎。然后他们继续从紧张的劳动力市场中受益。追随碧昂斯主角的年轻人，如果想要更多钱，可以辞掉工作，另谋高就。

;

;在美国，16 人的时薪增长- 24岁以下的人最近同比达到13%，而25岁至54岁的工人则为6%。这是有可靠数据以来最高的“年轻人溢价”（见图3）。在英国，年轻人的工资衡量方式不同，去年18岁至21岁的人平均每小时工资上涨了惊人的15%，大大超过了其他年龄段的工资涨幅。在新西兰，20 至 24 岁人群的平均每小时工资增长了 10%，而平均工资为 6%。

;
;;
;

;强劲的工资增长提高了家庭收入。智库美国企业研究所的凯文·科林斯 (Kevin Corinth) 和美联储的杰夫·拉里莫尔 (Jeff Larrimore) 发表了一篇新论文，在考虑了税收、政府转移支付和通货膨胀后，按代评估了美国人的家庭收入（见图 4）。当千禧一代同龄时，他们的生活状况比 X 一代（1965 年至 1980 年出生的人）要好一些。然而，Zoom 一代的生活比同龄的千禧一代要好得多。 25 岁的 Z 世代平均家庭年收入超过 40,000 美元，比同龄婴儿潮一代的平均收入高出 50% 以上。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Gen Z 的经济实力在罗德里戈女士最近在纽约举行的一场音乐会上得到了展示。出席的大部分是女性青少年和 20 多岁的人，他们花了数百美元买了一张票。售卖 50 美元 ;T; 衬衫的商品摊位前排起了长队，排满了竞技场。随着罗德里戈女士的巡演跨越大西洋，她在世界其他地区转移商品不会遇到任何麻烦。部分原因是，进入职场的 Z 世代在富裕国家赚了很多钱。 2007年，法国16岁至24岁人群的平均纯收入占总体平均水平的87%。现在等于92%。在包括克罗地亚和斯洛文尼亚在内的一些地方，Z 世代现在带来的收入与平均水平相当。

;

;一些 Z 世代提出抗议，声称更高的收入只是海市蜃楼，因为它们没有考虑到大学和住房费用的爆炸性增长。毕竟，全球房价已接近历史高位，毕业生背负的债务也比以前更多。但事实上，Z 世代正在应对，因为他们的收入很高。 2022 年，25 岁​​以下的美国人将 43% 的税后收入用于住房和教育，包括大学债务利息——略低于 1989 年至 2019 年 25 岁以下人群的平均水平。他们的住房拥有率高于千禧一代。同龄。他们的税后收入储蓄也比 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代的年轻人更多。换句话说，他们的生活状况更好。

;
;;
;

;这笔财富意味着什么？千禧一代似乎从小就认为工作是一种特权，并采取了相应的行动。他们对老板毕恭毕敬，渴望取悦老板。相比之下，Zoomers 从小就相信工作基本上是一种权利，这意味着他们对工作有不同的态度。去年，Z 世代吹嘘“安静退出”，即他们付出了足够的努力才不被解雇。其他人则谈论“最低限度星期一”。寻求从专横的男性手中夺取企业控制权的“女老板”原型对千禧一代的女性很有吸引力。 Z 世代更有可能讨论成为“蜗牛女孩”的想法，她们慢慢地做事并优先考虑自我保健。

;

;数据支持模因。 2022 年，15 至 24 岁的美国人花在“工作和与工作相关的活动”上的时间比 2007 年减少了 25%。;IMF 发表的一篇新论文;分析了人们表示愿意花在“工作和与工作相关的活动”上的时间喜欢工作。不久前，年轻人比老年人更愿意工作。现在他们想减少工作量。根据圣地亚哥州立大学 Jean Twenge 的分析，美国 12 年级学生（17 岁或 18 岁）将工作视为“生活的核心部分”的比例急剧下降。

;

;另一个后果是 Z 世代成为企业家的可能性较小。我们估计，欧盟 20 多岁的人中只有 1.1% 经营着雇用他人的企业，而近年来这一比例有所下降。根据《福布斯》杂志的统计，2000 年代末，全球超过 1% 的亿万富翁是千禧一代。当时，专家们痴迷于超年轻的科技创始人，例如马克·扎克伯格（Facebook）、帕特里克·科里森（Stripe）和埃文·斯皮格尔（Snapchat）。相比之下，如今《福布斯》榜单上 Zoomers 的比例还不到 0.5%。谁能说出一位著名的 Z 世代初创公司创始人的名字？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Z 世代的创新成果也越来越少。明尼苏达大学的拉塞尔·芬克 (Russell Funk) 表示，与最近相比，年轻人申请专利的可能性降低了。或者考虑一下 Billboard Hot 100，衡量美国最受欢迎的歌曲。 2008 年，42% 的热门歌曲是由千禧一代演唱的； 15 年后，只有 29% 的歌曲是由 Z 世代演唱的。泰勒·斯威夫特 (Taylor Swift) 是世界上最受欢迎的创作型歌手，她以她的出生年份命名了她最著名的专辑“1989”。世界仍在等待有人制作《2004​​》。

;

;Z世代的经济优势还能持续多久？经济衰退对年轻人的打击比其他人更严重，经济衰退总是如此。人工智能可能会破坏全球经济的稳定，即使年轻人最终可能会更好地从这种破坏中受益。不过，就目前而言，Z 世代有很多值得高兴的事情。在麦迪逊广场花园的演出间隙，奥利维亚·罗德里戈坐在钢琴前，建议她的歌迷感谢他们所拥有的一切。 “成长真是太棒了，”她说。 “你有足够的时间去做你想做的所有事情。”时间;和;金钱。 ;■;

;伊朗对以色列的政策已朝着两件事迈进了两件事。用对手站立鼻子。首先是从以色列邻近地区发动攻击的能力。伊朗希望能够通过广泛的袭击来威胁以色列，从滋扰袭击到大规模地面和导弹袭击。因此，其在叙利亚和黎巴嫩的代理人非常重要。第二个感知的要求是与以色列相匹配的核武器系统。伊朗尚未实现这一目标，只有一个人才能猜测其领导者一旦获得了能力。

Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (or ;BJP;) is widely predicted to win again.但国大党的忠诚者们希望，这将有助于在未来几年重振该党，并将甘地先生定位为 2029 年更强有力的挑战者。他们表示，到那时，公众对失业和不平等的愤怒可能会削弱莫迪先生的支持率。甘地先生还有时间。 At 53, he is two decades younger than Mr Modi.

;

;The question, then, is no longer if Mr Gandhi has the stomach for the斗争。问题在于，这位受过剑桥教育、有一半意大利血统的政治王朝后裔是否是改革这个政党的合适人选，甚至一些盟友也将这个政党比作功能失调的家族企业。效忠者认为，该党需要一个甘地来将其凝聚在一起，而拉胡尔在他的两阶段跨印度巡演中证明了自己的勇气，其中大部分巡演都是他步行完成的。 But after a series of high-profile defections, even some supporters are starting to wonder if a third consecutive general election loss should signal the end of the Gandhi family's nearly eight-decade grip on the party.

;

;To be fair to Mr Gandhi, the odds have been stacked against him lately.莫迪限制了媒体、司法和民间社会的独立性。他的税务和调查机构已针对数十名反对派政客，逮捕了两名反对党领导人，并冻结了国会银行账户。甘地先生本人正因涉嫌洗钱而受到调查（他否认有不当行为），并因嘲笑莫迪先生的名字而被判诽谤罪，并于 2023 年被停职四个月。 So uneven is the contest that Congress leaders recently discussed boycotting the poll.

;

;Nonetheless, Congress is still the only viable national alternative to the ;BJP;. Although Congress' national vote share has declined steadily from a peak of 49% in 1984 to 20% in 2019 (see chart) it retains a hard core of support among secular-minded Indians, Muslims and other minorities, especially in the south. And there is still a pathway back to national power—if Mr Gandhi can confront three urgent challenges that are within his purview.

;;
;;
;

;The first is ideological. In the last decade, Congress has struggled to identify a coherent message to compete with the ;BJP;'s combination of Hindutva (Hindu nationalism) and development.将莫迪视为对民主的威胁并不会削弱他在占多数的印度教徒中的支持​​基础，其中许多人钦佩他强有力的领导能力。国会领导人涉足“软印度教”，与圣人闲聊，并高调参拜寺庙。 But that seems only to anger Congress stalwarts, while failing to steal ;BJP; votes.

;

;Recently, Congress has made inequality its central campaign theme. A manifesto, released on April 5th (and denounced by Mr Modi as pro-Muslim), made commitments including a legal right to apprenticeship, a minimum support price for farmers, cash transfers of 100,000 rupees to poor families and a minimum wage of 400 rupees日常的。 It promised to do a nationwide census of all groups in the Hindu caste system, to strengthen an affirmative-action scheme and to reverse several ;BJP; policies it considers anti-democratic.

;;

;It's not just the economy

;

;The manifesto also pledged to create millions of jobs in manufacturing and mining.但对政府干预和施舍的关注（几乎没有如何为其融资的细节）给它带来了明显的左翼味道。这在一定程度上反映了甘地先生的个人政治观点。同事们表示，他更关心的是更均匀地分配经济增长，而不是促进经济增长。 “大多数印度政客都会接受不平等作为经济快速增长的代价，”该党发言人杰拉姆·拉梅什 (Jairam Ramesh) 表示。 “He refuses.”

;

;There is a logic to Mr Gandhi's leftwards tilt. To counter the ;BJP;'s majoritarianism, he seeks to mobilise lower castes and minorities that represent around 80% of Indians.尽管如此，财富和特权的产物仍然很难推销。相比之下，莫迪是一位茶叶商的儿子，种姓相对较低。 He has won many votes among the poor by expanding digital welfare. And the ;BJP; pledged more handouts in its own manifesto, released on April 14th (and denounced by Congress as an “empty jugglery of words”).

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;More troubling still for Congress is the apparent disconnect between voters' everyday concerns and their political choices.尽管许多人关心失业问题并希望进行种姓普查，但他们仍然支持莫迪先生。德里智库政策研究中心的拉胡尔·维尔马表示，这表明许多选民不相信国会能够兑现承诺，尤其是在就业方面。该党也不能像莫迪在 2014 年之前对古吉拉特邦那样引用最近发生转变的国家。 “国会面临的挑战更加艰巨，因为它执政了很长时间，”维尔马先生说。 “It comes with baggage.”

;

;Mr Gandhi's second big challenge is organisational. The ;BJP;'s recent electoral success is based, in part, on its ruthlessly efficient party management and messaging.相比之下，国会的决策缓慢、不透明，有时甚至不稳定。 It has often been reluctant to jettison candidates loyal to the Gandhi family, even after they lost elections.

;

;Its message discipline is also notoriously sloppy.国会高级官员经常公开表示不同意见，或者说出令联盟伙伴不安的话。去年，该党对哈马斯袭击以色列的反应发生了转变。一月份，国大党领导人在是否参加莫迪为一座有争议的印度教寺庙举行的落成仪式上存在公开分歧。 And in March, one senior Party figure wrote an open letter challenging its support for the caste census.

;

;Two years ago, the party tried to enlist Prashant Kishor, a prominent electoral strategist who helped engineer the ;BJP;'s 2014 victory (and is now starting a new political party).他向甘地家族提出了一项详细计划，以彻底改革国会的组织方式、挑选候选人和开展竞选活动的方式。他们拒绝了。 “他们还没有准备好接受问题的存在，他们需要改变，”基肖尔先生说。 “They still believe that this is just a temporary phase, that it will blow over, and sooner or later they will be back.”

;

;甘地先生面临的第三个挑战更加个人化。尽管现在更加精力充沛，但他仍然更喜欢政治的知识方面。虽然他喜欢对社会问题进行深入讨论，但他不喜欢管理政党及其联盟所需的交易。当他遇到阻力时，他对倡议的热情常常会减弱。而且他缺乏行政经验，从未管理过国家或部委。 “甘地只是总理，”一位前党内人士回忆说，在国大党执政期间提议甘地先生加入内阁后，有人告诉他。

;
;;
;

;A bigger concern is that Mr Gandhi lacks the steeliness to grasp control of his party. 2000年代，他领导了一场引进新鲜血液的运动，为青年派举行公开选举，并承诺对党的领导层也进行同样的选举。这带来了年轻人才的涌入。但在接下来的十年里，他们一再受到国会元老的排挤，导致许多后起之秀的叛逃。自 2019 年以来，至少有 25 名知名人士逃离了国会。 Failure to overrule party elders contributed to its defeat in three state elections last year.

;

;Some party insiders worry that Mr Gandhi is still in limbo, neither fully in control of Congress nor willing to let others take charge. 2019年辞去党魁职务后，他的意大利出生的母亲索尼娅接替了他的职位。 2022 年，国会资深人士马利卡琼·哈格 (Mallikarjun Kharge) 接替了她。但现年 81 岁的哈格先生无法与莫迪先生相比，决策仍然由甘地家族和一群家族忠诚者主导。 So far, the party has not nominated a prime ministerial candidate, leaving Mr Modi with no direct rival.

;

;Congress officials say Mr Kharge's appointment proves the party's commitment to meritocracy.此外，他们补充道，这不是一场总统竞选；而是一场总统竞选。总理通常是在选举后选出的。即便如此，甘地在党内的模糊角色让他很容易被认为是在逃避与莫迪正面交锋的说法。如果国会想要在未来几年扭转颓势，甘地先生将不得不做出选择：挺身而出还是下台。 ;■;

;;O;;N APRIL 2ND; a contraption resembling a snow machine on the deck of the ;USS Hornet;, a defunct aircraft-carrier moored in San Francisco Bay, began producing a mist of salty aerosol particles. The scientific collaboration behind the project, the Marine Cloud Brightening (;MCB;) programme, led by the University of Washington, is investigating whether such aerosols might help to slow climate change through a form of “geoengineering”. What does this term mean—and why is it so controversial?

;

;In 2009 Britain's Royal Society, a scientific academy, defined geoengineering as “the deliberate large-scale manipulation of the planetary environment to counteract anthropogenic climate change”. It split approaches into two categories: those that make it easier for the Earth to lose heat, and those that reduce the amount of heat it gains. Carbon-dioxide removal (;CDR;) helps in the first way by lowering the level of greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, making it easier for heat to escape. Reducing the amount of energy the Earth absorbs from the Sun, known as ;solar geoengineering;, helps in the second way. The MCB experiment seeks to do this by increasing the number of “cloud condensation nuclei” in low marine clouds: that would raise the number of droplets that such clouds are made of while decreasing their size, so that they reflect more sunlight into space.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The technologies used for ;CDR; and suggested for solar geoengineering are completely different. But there are similarities in their potential ramifications. In the absence of either, the degree of warming the Earth will experience will be set by the total cumulative emissions of long-lived greenhouse gases. If ;CDR; were used to mop up some of those gases, or if solar geoengineering reduced the amount of sunshine getting in in the first place, that strict dependency would no longer hold.

;

;This introduces a risk often termed “moral hazard”. For as long as total emissions are the only thing that matters, the policy prescription is clear: emit less, come what may. If there are ways around total cumulative emissions, the need is not all-consuming. Some argue that this could reduce the urgency with which countries and businesses pursue emission cuts.

;

;There are other concerns about solar geoengineering. The most-studied technique requires the creation of a layer of fine particles in the stratosphere, similar to the cooling layers created by large volcanic explosions. That could have implications for the recovery of the ozone layer. It would have repercussions for weather patterns in the lower atmosphere, too, leading to changes in rainfall. The effects would depend on the details of the strategy implemented and would not be uniform; different approaches would bring benefits to some regions and could do harm to others. But unlike emissions reduction, which has to be undertaken by most big emitters to work, solar geoengineering can be done unilaterally. This sounds like a recipe for conflict.

;

;As a result, solar geoengineering remains a fringe issue. By contrast, in the 15 years since the Royal Society's report, ;CDR; has ;become mainstream;. The idea of “net-zero” emissions, now central to lots of government and corporate climate policies, relies on it. ;CDR; is considered palatable because, by removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, it reduces greenhouse warming in a permanent way. Solar geoengineering, by contrast, would allow for the continued accumulation of greenhouse gases, merely masking their warming effects for as long as the geoengineering continues. That would be a problem if solar geoengineering efforts were suddenly to be stopped for some reason; the masked warming effects of the accumulated greenhouse gases would quickly kick back in. This risk, among others, and the sense that accepting all solar geoengineering's geophysical and geopolitical risks still only gets the world a temporary patch leads some proponents of ;CDR; to resent the two approaches being lumped together.

;

;Given the controversy around solar geoengineering, why would anyone want to research it? Because unlike ;CDR; it could work quickly: a stratospheric solar-geoengineering programme might start to cool the Earth within a year. None of the researchers investigating its potential thinks that it should displace emissions reduction. But they do think that its potential merits study nonetheless. ;■;

;;U;;GANDA'S PRESIDENT;, Yoweri Museveni, used to tell young women to produce more children. He said a large population would attract more investors. But since 2012 Mr Museveni has advised Ugandan women against many pregnancies, warning them that they will weaken their bodies and struggle to bring up several children. In recent decades rapidly improving health care has driven a baby boom in sub-Saharan Africa, putting pressure on schools and health services. Fertility rates are ;tumbling elsewhere,; including in China and India, which account for more than a third of the global population. By the turn of the century, the share of the world's babies born in sub-Saharan Africa is forecast to reach 55%, from 30% in 2021. And people will be living longer. The continent's population is thus set to double by 2050.

;;;

;A new study published in the ;Lancet;, a medical journal, provides a comprehensive breakdown of fertility trends in each of the world's regions. The authors compare total fertility rates (;TFR;s), meaning the average number of children a woman is expected to have in her lifetime (see chart 1). When making forecasts they account for factors often omitted, such as levels of female education, population density and rates of contraceptive use.

;

;The study finds that the global ;TFR; has fallen by more than half from 4.84 in 1950, the earliest recorded measure, to 2.23 in 2021. Meanwhile, in sub-Saharan Africa, it has fallen more slowly and remains close to 4.29 。 The continent has almost half of the 94 countries with a ;TFR; of above 2.1, the “replacement rate” at which a population is stable in the long run.

;;;
;

;But the gap between sub-Saharan Africa and other regions is closing (see chart 2). By 2075 the region's ;TFR; is expected to drop below 2.1. By the end of the century, it will be 1.82, approaching current levels in Ireland and Denmark. That is driven by improving education and job prospects, especially for women. Contraception is also becoming more common in the region. In Senegal, for example, contraception use among married women has doubled to 26% in the decade to 2023; in Kenya more than half of them use it.

;

;According to the ;Lancet; study, the convergence between regional rates could happen even faster than predicted by the ;UN;. This is in line with other recent studies, which suggest that fertility rates are falling ;faster than expected;. Researchers believe this may be in part because of a push in recent decades to improve girls' education, as well as a recent uptick in the use of contraception.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Those demographic factors will play out differently in various parts of sub-Saharan Africa. More children will continue to be born in poorer places. Governments can also offer women better family-planning services and invest more in education. In Angola, for instance, women without schooling have 7.8 children, whereas those with tertiary education have 2.3. The; Lancet; study projects that if universal female education or universal contraceptive needs were met by 2030, the region's ;TFR; would fall to 2.3 in 2050, compared with 2.7 at the current trends. That is probably not attainable. But it should motivate governments to try. ;■;

;;T;;here are;, writes Sir Salman Rushdie, “three important characters” in “Knife”, a new memoir of his ;near-fatal stabbing in August 2022; and his arduous recovery.前两个是可以预见的：作者和他的持刀袭击者。 The third character turns this chronicle of violence into a surprisingly tender and redemptive story.

;

;Sir Salman was about to speak at a festival in upstate New York when a black-clad man charged the stage. His first thought was: “So it's you.给你。” It was 33 years since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran had called for his death because of the alleged blasphemy of his novel, “The Satanic Verses”. It was more than 20 since he moved to America after years of police protection in Britain. Now the half-expected, still-astonishing assassin was upon him. “I raise my left hand in self-defence. He plunges the knife into it.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And into his neck, face, abdomen and eye—15 wounds in a 27-second frenzy.他指出，暴力让受害者感到困惑：“现实消失了，取而代之的是难以理解的事物。”但他足够警觉，认为这就是结束了。在一本既充满激情又不抱幻想的书中，他明确表示没有灵魂出窍的经历：“我的身体快要死了，它也带走了我。”他似乎不太可能活下来，但被缝合并钉在一起。 His blinded eye bulged from its socket “like a large soft-boiled egg”.

;

;Only after a few weeks did Sir Salman see his disfigured face in the mirror. When he left hospital there were more scares and treatments and nightmares. He dreamed of the blinding of Gloucester in “King Lear”; he thought of the knife that kills Kafka's protagonist in “The Trial”. Among the supporting cast in “Knife” is the knife itself—at once a cold, sharp object and a metaphor for hatred, fanaticism and life's ruptures.

;

;Intermittently he thinks of the second character, the young Lebanese-American who has pleaded not guilty to attempted murder and assault, and who, typically, had barely opened “The Satanic Verses”. Omitting his name—he is “My Assailant”, then “the A”—Sir Salman wavers over whether he wants to confront him. Instead he makes up a jokey-serious dialogue between them, probing the imaginary suspect about faith, failure and loneliness. “You aren't capable of understanding me,” the suspect insists. Standing outside the jail where the real man was awaiting trial, Sir Salman had an urge to dance.

;

;All he wanted was to be a novelist, but the ayatollah and the knife have made him a global champion of free speech. He reaffirms its value here. “Without art,” he writes, “our ability to think, to see freshly, and to renew our world would wither and die.” He decries the “false narratives” of bigots and autocrats and extols openness and debate. “Language was my knife”, he avers, “the tool I would use to remake and reclaim my world.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet the principal riposte to the brutality in “Knife” comes from its third main character: Rachel Eliza Griffiths, an American writer and photographer and Sir Salman's fifth wife.他以法医的细节讲述了他们相遇并坠入爱河的“抛硬币时刻”，以及他令人眼花缭乱的迷恋和最终的求婚。 All this is more than a gushy ode: it is essential to his underlying themes.

;

;One of those is time. His next thought, up on that stage, was: “Why now?” The knifeman was “a murderous ghost” seeking “to drag me back in time”. The past, he sees, is both inescapable and fixed. He poses lots of questions and what-ifs about the assault, including why he “just stood there like a piñata”. He nearly pulled out of the talk but needed the fee for an air-conditioning bill. He knows, though, that time allows no do-overs. Nor, because of Eliza, does he ultimately want it to: “We would not be who we are today without the calamities of our yesterdays.”

;

;His other deep theme is the challenge of living in a bleak world; or, to put it another way, the riddle of human nature. He “experienced both the worst and best” when onlookers tackled his attacker and saved his life. Above all, however, the counterbalance to evil is the love and devotion of Eliza, with whom Sir Salman salvaged “a wounded happiness”.

;

; 《刀》是一个关于袭击的爱情故事，在袭击和另一个中心场景之间的倾斜对称中捕捉到了一个悖论。遇见伊丽莎的那天晚上，萨尔曼爵士笨手笨脚地走进了一扇玻璃门。他躺在地板上，血从脸上流下来，直到她服侍他。然后他站了起来，现在他又胜利地站了起来。 ;■;

;;S;;arnies and; precision engineering may seem to be worlds apart.但英国最大的三明治制造商 Greencore 每年在工业机器人上花费 2000 万英镑（2500 万美元）。他们对牛油果进行去皮、切片和去核。他们使用超声波刀将卷饼和法棍面包切成两半。他们将面包片放在馅料上。 They also help make sushi.

;

;Machines have not solved all of Greencore's problems. They're unable to make a classic ;BLT; (bacon, lettuce and tomato) sandwich, whose toppings are hyper-sensitive to bruising from heavy machinery. “The software exists but the dexterity of the robot is not where it needs to be,” says Dalton Philips, Greencore's ;CEO;.机器人在其他任务上也遇到了困难。该公司的工人每周手工包装数百万个三明治。 But where they can help, machines make a huge difference, saving 350 hours of manual labour each week on sushi-making alone.

;;
;;
;

;In a country where ;productivity growth has been anaemic; for 15 years, such gains are not to be sniffed at. Yet Britain has the lowest adoption rate for robots in the ;G;7 (see chart). The country deploys around 98 robots for every 10,000 workers in manufacturing, compared with more than ten times that amount in South Korea and around four times that number in Germany, Japan and China, according to the International Federation of Robots (;IFR;), a trade body. A study by Copenhagen Business School has estimated that Japan-like levels of automation would boost Britain's productivity by over a fifth.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;You might expect economies that are more dependent on manufacturing to be further ahead when it comes to investing in robots.如今，制造业仅占英国经济的 8%，低于 1970 年的 27%； in South Korea and Japan, manufacturing accounts for 26% and 19% of ;GDP ;respectively.但即使与其他服务导向型经济体相比，英国仍然落后。 For every 10,000 workers in manufacturing, America has 285 robots and France 180.

;

;Bright spots exist.英国汽车行业每万名员工拥有734台机器人； Jaguar Land Rover's Solihull plant boasts more than 615 high-tech robots with a Jaguar ;XE; rolling off the assembly line every 78 seconds.自动化在物流领域也很普遍，机器人在仓库中提升和分类物品。但其他行业却落后了。 London Economics, a consultancy, estimates that robots will perform just 1% of tasks in construction and agriculture by 2035, despite up to 38% and 30% of functions in these industries being suited to machines.

;

;There are several reasons for the slow overall pace of automation, some more tractable than others.从英国脱欧的剧变到政策制定者的反复无常，几乎可以肯定的是，不确定性在抑制投资方面发挥了作用——英国的资本补贴制度在四十年里经历了多达 24 次变化。慷慨的资本投资全额费用制度现已到位； the Labour Party has promised to keep it if it wins the next election.

;

;The availability of cheap foreign labour in the past is thought by many to have ;muted incentives; to invest in machines.自大流行以来经济高度不活跃以及更严格的移民规则给雇主施加了更大的自动化压力。 So is an ageing workforce, which is ;highly correlated with investment in robots;.据行业机构工程建筑行业培训委员会称，到 2026 年，英国五分之一的工程师将退休或接近退休。 Robot installations across Britain for food and drinks companies like Greencore were up by 76% in 2022, according to the ;IFR;. ;ABB;, a big Swiss-Swedish industrial-technology firm, says that Britain was one of its best countries for revenue growth last year.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But the obstacles to large-scale adoption remain formidable.英国缺乏足够的具备安装和操作现代工具技能的工人。学徒制的缺乏意味着学位以下的熟练技术人员供不应求。 Half of German school-leavers take up vocational training, with a third opting for apprenticeships, compared with just 7% of those in Britain.

;

;Britain is also an economy of small (and often ;poorly managed;) companies, which sits uncomfortably with the high fixed costs of machinery.工人数量不足 10 人的企业雇用了全国三分之一的劳动力； around a fifth of German workers and a tenth of American ones work for firms of that size.

;

;A poll of 500 smaller businesses in 2023, by Charles & Dean, a finance broker, found that less than half of firms took advantage of a now-defunct “super deduction” scheme, which cut £1.30 from companies' tax bills for every £1 invested in new machinery. Even with a generous tax break, one in five firms said they could not afford to invest. The average dairy farm in Britain is expected to earn a profit of £50,000 this year, for instance. Yet for a herd of 200 cows, milking robots can cost as much as £400,000 to buy.

;

;The good news is that the costs of automation are falling. Doubling the cumulative number of industrial robots produced leads to their prices falling by half, according to ;ARK; Invest, an investment-management firm. That should help accelerate the slow spread of robots in Britain. Even if they cannot yet make a ;BLT;. ;■;

;;W;;hen China's; leaders set an economic-growth target of “around” 5% for this year, the goal was universally described as ambitious.现在，该国实现这一目标的可能性似乎越来越大。花旗集团、高盛和摩根士丹利等多家外资银行最近上调了预测。 Figures released on April 16th showed the economy grew by 5.3% in the first quarter, compared with a year earlier—quicker than expected and faster than the target requires.

;

;How is this happening?处于中国发展阶段的国家往往会转向服务业。但中国领导人对“硬”产出情有独钟。中国领导人习近平将制造业视为繁荣和安全的源泉。他觊觎官方所说的“完整”产业链，使中国在重要技术投入方面摆脱对外国势力的依赖。 To that end, his latest five-year plan aims to stop the steady decline in manufacturing's share of ;GDP;.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The first three months of this year were consistent with that long-term goal.制造业产出同比增长6.7%，快于整体经济。高科技制造业表现更好，增长了 7.5%。 China's leaders have talked a lot about the need to cultivate “;new quality productive forces;”, buzzwords that appeared in the monthly press release from the National Bureau of Statistics for the first time, even if the statisticians did not elaborate on how these forces could be measured.

;

;China is determined to wean itself off foreign suppliers.然而，今年头几个月突显了一种不同类型的依赖：对外国买家的依赖。品点资产管理公司张志伟表示，中国一季度出口额同比增长14%。价格下跌和具有竞争力的货币有所帮助。美国劳工统计局数据显示，第一季度来自中国的商品价格同比下降2.9%。 That is the third-steepest drop on record.

;

;Some analysts worry that China cannot rely on strong exports for long without provoking a protectionist backlash from它的贸易伙伴。德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) 4 月 16 日在北京会见习近平时表达了对中国产能过剩的担忧。欧洲最大的经济体曾经受益于中国的经济进步。尽管中国制造商征服了世界各地的低端市场，但它仍向中国出售先进的工业产品。 Now the two countries have become rivals in many industries Germany holds dear, including chemicals, machinery and, of course, cars.

;

;China's reliance on markets abroad reflects some enduring weaknesses at home.三月份的零售销售出人意料地糟糕。消费者信心仍然很低。房地产市场的痛苦仍在继续。据路透社报道，3月份中国70个大城市的新房价格同比平均下降2.2%，创2015年以来最大降幅。 Sales of newly built residential housing fell by over a fifth.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The slump in China's property market has contributed to falling prices in many related parts of the economy, such as building materials and housing appliances.这加深了通货紧缩对经济的影响。出厂价格现已连续 18 个月下降。消费者价格通胀在 2 月份农历新年假期期间短暂上涨后，3 月份仍接近于零。 Declining prices are, of course, a double-edged sword, as Ting Lu of Nomura, a bank, has pointed out.它们提高了中国的海外竞争力，这也是该国出口异常强劲的原因之一。但如果通货紧缩持续存在，可能会侵蚀收入，使债务更难以承担。 It might also force companies to cut wages, which will do nothing to restore household morale or spending.

;

;For all the paranoia of China's leaders, they seem worryingly complacent about the danger of deflation.或许他们认为这只是一个昙花一现，但这不应该分散他们对加强中国抵御全球力量平衡变化（习近平所说的“百年未有之变”）的长期目标的注意力。不过，价格下跌可能会将暂时的低迷变成长期的低迷。 This week's figures showed that China's ;GDP ;deflator, a broad measure of prices, has fallen for four quarters in a row.自 1999 年以来，这种情况从未发生过。或者用习近平可能会欣赏的话说，这是本世纪未曾见过的变化。 ;■;

;

;更直接的是大规模饥饿的风险。荷兰智库 Clingendael Institute 的一项研究显示，“最有可能发生的情况”预计，到 6 月，苏丹大部分地区将遭遇饥荒，造成 50 万人死亡。在其“极端”情景预测中，多达一百万人可能死亡。由于战争，苏丹大部分地区（尤其是达尔富尔）在 2023 年几乎没有收成。全国谷物产量几乎下降了一半；基本食品价格上涨高达83%。随着战斗现已蔓延到杰齐拉的粮仓州，这些趋势将会恶化。

;战争双方都在阻碍人道主义援助。 ;RSF;战士经常袭击属于;NGO;的援助卡车和战利品仓库。二月份，;苏丹武装部队;禁止援助机构通过乍得运送物资。此后，政府态度有所缓和，但继续扣留援助人员的签证和旅行许可证。一位;联合国;官员指出，跨越;新加坡武装部队;和;RSF;控制的领土之间的界限来提供援助是“麻烦且故意耗时的” 。结果，整个地区的紧急供应已经中断了几个月。塔夫茨大学饥荒专家亚历克斯·德瓦尔表示：“苏丹以前的粮食危机都是局部性的。” “现在我们正在目睹自 19 世纪以来从未见过的事情：全国范围内的粮食紧急情况。”

;考虑一下北达尔富尔州首府法希尔和<小>;新加坡武装部队;在西部的最后一个主要据点。 Before the war, the city was a sanctuary for those escaping violence and hunger elsewhere: tens, if not hundreds, of thousands of civilians had sheltered there since the previous round of ethnic cleansing in Darfur 20 years ago.然而如今，这只是苏丹其他地区普遍混乱的一个缩影。理论上，国家军队仍然负责，数千名士兵躲在市中心的军营里。但实际上，当地扎格哈瓦族的叛乱分子提供了大部分安全保障，而郊区的大部分地区则处于;RSF;及其附属民兵的控制之下。从城市的一侧穿越到另一侧意味着要经过多个检查站，每个检查站都由不同的武装团体把守。尽管军队经常对;无国界支援部队;阵地进行空袭，但最终往往会袭击平民地区，包括自己控制下的地区。

Every two hours in Zamzam, a refugee camp on the south-western side, a child dies from lack of food or medical care, says Médecins Sans Frontières, another French charity. With new arrivals streaming into the city from other parts of Darfur, basic supplies are dwindling.尽管市场上仍然可以买到食物，但价格却贵得离谱：一袋大米的价格几乎是战前的八倍。

;;D;;ESPITE ITS; 45 岁对“小撒旦”的敌意，;伊朗从未开过一枪从以色列自己的领土攻击以色列。伊斯兰共和国创始人阿亚图拉鲁霍拉·霍梅尼表示，通往耶路撒冷的道路相反，要经过什叶派圣地伊拉克城市卡尔巴拉，因此他与伊拉克开战。自 1989 年起担任伊朗最高领袖的阿亚图拉阿里·哈梅内伊利用其代理人——真主党、黎巴嫩什叶派民兵以及巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯和伊斯兰圣战组织——来;打击以色列目标;并避免直接对抗。近年来，当以色列在首都德黑兰袭击伊朗核计划及其科学家时，哈梅内伊的顾问呼吁保持“战略耐心”。

;一切都变了。伊朗前驻黎巴嫩大使艾哈迈德·达斯特马奇安 (Ahmad Dastmalchian) 表示，4 月 13 日，伊朗向以色列发射了 300 多架无人机、巡航导弹和弹道导弹，预示着“范式转变”。火力让很多伊朗人震惊，远远超过了伊朗为回应 2020 年美国刺杀其最高将领卡西姆·苏莱马尼而发出的齐射。伊朗伊斯兰革命卫队 (;IRGC;) 负责人侯赛因·萨拉米 (Hossein Salami) 少将表示，该政权目前正在采取行动与“一个新方程”。 4 月 14 日，伊朗总统的一位顾问在 X（以前的 Twitter）上表示：“战略耐心的时代已经结束。”

;外国压力部分解释了政策变化。自十月份加沙战争爆发以来，以色列加大了对整个中东地区伊朗目标的攻击力度。它在对叙利亚和黎巴嫩的袭击中杀死了 18 名<小>;伊斯兰革命卫队;指挥官和约 250 名真主党战士。 4 月 1 日对大马士革伊朗外交官邸的空袭证明，伊朗的代理人不再提供其长期以来所依赖的威慑力。

;

;但国内力量也在影响决策。在哈梅内伊职业生涯的大部分时间里，他都依赖像他一样粗暴的保守实用​​主义者。许多人是该政权最强大的战斗力量<小>;伊斯兰革命卫队;的指挥官，如果他们认为这样做可以巩固该政权，他们就准备与西方合作。但最近，一群意识形态顽固分子崛起，他们之于伊朗，就像宗教强硬右派之于以色列一样。佩达里阵线（Paydari Front）或伊斯兰革命稳定阵线是什叶派至上主义者，反对与伊朗境内外的任何人进行任何形式的妥协。他们嘲笑批评者是无神论者和反革命分子，并希望将德黑兰的公园变成清真寺。他们认为与西方的任何形式的和解都是令人厌恶的，以至于他们中的一些人在议会烧毁了《联合全面行动计划》的文本，该协议是伊朗于 2015 年与世界六国签署的限制其核计划的协议。他们将面对以色列袭击的“战略耐心”比作绥靖政策。

;

;他们的反对者谈到了国家占领。 Ebrahim Raisi, the hardline cleric who was elected president in 2021, has given them prominent positions in his government.他的岳父也许是伊朗最激进的神职人员。他的布道激发了帕达里人的热情。在上个月的议会选举中，由于许多人抵制投票，他们加强了对权力的控制。佩达里阵线候选人击败了穆罕默德·巴格尔·卡利巴夫 (Mohammaed Bagher Qalibaf)，他是一位务实的德黑兰前市长、<小>;伊斯兰革命卫队;指挥官，也是哈梅内伊先生的亲戚。他们现在正寻求罢免他的议长职务。他们通过了新的贞操法。他们不顾<小>;伊斯兰革命卫队;老前辈的建议，寻求在 2022 年广泛抗议后事实上暂停强制戴头巾后重新实施强制戴头巾。在伊朗袭击以色列的同一天，他们派出了道德警察时隔一年，重返街头。

;

;Paydari Front 的神职人员还渗透到<小>;伊斯兰革命卫队;的队伍中。最新一代的指挥官在他们的职业生涯中参加了由帕达里神职人员管理的夏令营，其中许多人也被派往他们的部队。田纳西大学查塔努加分校;IRGC;专家 Saeid Golkar 表示：“新一代的意识形态更加偏激、粗鲁，经验较少，也不太务实。”与前几代人不同，他们对 20 世纪 80 年代的两伊战争没有记忆。他们利用宗教文本来制定策略。 “那些不懂战争的人更渴望战斗，”他引用伊朗的一句谚语说道。
